newsitem.title: UK: Major stock movements overnight - May 13.
newsitem.headline: Major stock movements overnight - May 13.

text.p: LONDON - Britain's FTSE 100 index scaled its seventh consecutive record high on Monday, fuelled by another rally on Wall Street and unexpected news of a 23-billion stg merger between Grand Metropolitan Plc and Guinness Plc . The FTSE finished 38.7 points higher at 4,669.6.

FRANKFURT - German shares got the week off to a solid start on Monday, as a surge in Deutsche Telekom AG helped the blue chip DAX index to a record closing high. Surprising some dealers who had expected a more muted beginning, the 30-share DAX ended the bourse session up 12.96 points, or 0.36 percent, at
3,575.37. In post-bourse trade the index was up 59.93 at 3,593.14.

PARIS - French shares closed with a jump of more than two percent, ending just below 2,700 on the CAC index, pushed by a storming rise on the Dow Jones stock index in New York, traders said. The CAC-40 closed up 59.18 points or 2.25 percent at 2,693.09.

ZURICH - Swiss shares shook off early weakness to end at a record closing high, propelled by a firming U.S. dollar which drove stocks of export-dependent firms higher. The Broad Swiss Performance Index (SPI) added 19.49 points, or 0.62 percent, to close at 3,187.48.

TOKYO - Tokyo stocks closed sharply higher on Monday, as the key market index recaptured the key 20,000 level on the dollar's partial recovery from a near four-month low against the yen. The Nikkei 225 average gained 340.73 points or 1.72 percent to close at 20,143.51.

HONG KONG - Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index broke more records on Monday as another rally in HSBC Holdings spearheaded a drive to an all-time intra-day high before blue chips settled at a record close on record turnover. The Hang Seng Index closed 57.00 points, or 0.41 percent, higher at 13,987.80.

SYDNEY - The Australian share market ended a choppy day's trade little changed on Monday with a falling afternoon futures market wiping out early record-breaking gains. The benchmark All Ordinaries index closed 1.2 points lower at 2,524.8.

JOHANNESBURG - South African gold shares end firmer on the back of a brighter bullion price, fixed in London this morning at a one-month high of $348.20 an ounce. Industrials finish weaker, cut by profit-taking in somewhat directionless trade and on disappointing gains on Wall Street last Friday. Industrials lose 25.1 points to 8,476.1, golds up 30.3 points to 1,267.9 and the all-share adds 10.9 points to 7,190.3.
